ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin and Peter Umunay were both equal teaching assistants for this class. They both commanded knowledge of the subject and were very helping during review sessions and field trips
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Probably Meredith, interacted with both though
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  both equally
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  I interacted with Peter and Meredith approximately an equal amount
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  I interacted with both Meredith and Peter equally.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  I interacted with both equally. Meredith was able often able to explain concepts more clearly on field trips, but it seemed this was due in large part to her knowledge of New England. I imagine it would be the reverse if in the DRC!
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was amazing- always helpful and supportive. She gave really concise, strong answers!

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  She was always open and willing to help. Her tutorial sessions were always very clear and helpful. Her help in the field trips was also very helpful, and she strived for us to really learn the fundamentals of what we were working on.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  I interacted with both Meredith and Peter. They both were great at answering questions either on field trips or during tutorial.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith is very knowledgable, responsive to questions and patient. She was very effective in answering my emails with doubts, even if they were not exactly related to our lectures.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Peter Mbanda Umunay  I interacted with both teaching assistants.
Instructor: Peter Mbanda Umunay  Friendly, helpful and gave good advise.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Neither TA had any weaknesses, although sometimes Meredith seemed more prepared than Peter. Overall they both did a wonderful job.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was wonderful, helping to make concepts that weren't clear in class very clear. She is the best! Definitely should be the TA again! Although I interacted less with Peter, he was also wonderful and helpful. And, so good at chopping roots out of the ground!
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  They were both responsive and knowledgeable, not sure what else to say
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  explained concepts very clearly and were available for tutorials and extra office hours.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Both seemed to know the material well. They also seemed to complement each other well. If one was not accessible, the other would certainly be.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Both were fantastic
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Sometimes the TAs could not anticipate what Mark had to say or was doing.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Her explanations are very clear, and the study questions she posed were always very helpful.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  There is a tremendous amount of material to cover in class and a lot of background material is needed to do well. Perhaps the TAs could do more workshops for people who haven't taken taxonomy or stands?
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Good tutorials and responsive to emails. I think she could have kept Mark on track more when he drifted around during lecture (we almost never ended on time).
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith is very knowledgable, responsive to questions and patient. She is an excellent tutor and was able to explain all the concepts very clearly and thoroughly.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Excellent. Meredith was accessible, quick to respond, and provided very well thought out review sessions and prep sessions for exams. She was approachable both through email, in class, and in person, and made me feel more confident in my abilities with the materials. Overall outstanding TA. I would be more likely to take another technical course if I knew she was the TA for it.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  She knew a lot and could effectively explain concepts to students. Was a great supplement to Ashton!

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  The tutorial format was very helpful to clarify concepts and not fall behind on lecture material. Having the tutorials scheduled well in advance was also very helpful. Both Teaching Fellows also provided good information on field trips. I would suggest that they could be more active in engaging with students on field trips to share information and to encourage students to ask questions.

Instructor: Peter Mbanda Umunay  Both teaching assistants were incredibly helpful for distilling complex concepts, and both went out of their way to help students who missed review sessions or who didn't grasp concepts. Both of the teaching fellows were incredibly passionate about the course and contributing to the students' learning and went above and beyond to ensure that students had a great experience in the course!
Instructor: Peter Mbanda Umunay  Peter came prepared for tutorials and the class proceeded in a easy to follow manner.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Overall this was a great class. The fieldtrips were fun (though there were a lot of them). I also really appreciated the break in the middle of class, along with the tea and coffee. My main criticism of this class is that Prof. Ashton often goes off on long tangents, really making it hard to stay focused on the lecture and the materials. Related to this, I thought there was too much talking at many of the field trips. It seems like the field trips should be used to actually do things, rather than just listen to more lectures. Less talking, more doing. Students can only absorb so much information at any time, so there's not much point in talking for so long.
Q 11: Sometimes difficult to tell what portion of lectures are important to write down, I appreciate the humor but one of the more challenging courses to take notes in
fast paced course with a lot of lecture time and field trip time. a lot of information to master in this course
I'm less interested in management, so place a slightly different value on the course than most students. However, I still think it does have a high value.
Better for the class to be conducted in the fall in view of the many field trips and the typical terrible weather during the winter-spring period.
Sometimes the lecturing was a bit circuitous. The tangential comments could be fewer.

I missed one class, and while I had the online readings and materials and studied those, I still felt like I missed a lot from the lecture (that was on the exam!). It was hard to know what I had missed.

Highly recommended to any student who will make decisions effecting ground-level management of forested and non-forested terrestrial areas. Did away with a few of my misconceptions about timbering and conservation of protected areas and left me with a solid base of applicable skills. I feel like I can walk into a forest and make basic, competent recommendations for its treatment.
Ashton - his lectures could be improved; sometimes he can ramble on and on, but part of the benefits taking classes with him is that you get to listen to everything he knows

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips complemented the lectures nicely and were a way to gain hand-on experience with the topics that were discussed in class.
Fieldtrips.
Yale Myers field trip
field trips made concepts a little more understandable.

Mark is so incredibly passionate about the subject material and has an encyclopedic memory of all of his research and that of others that allows him to draw upon a diversity of geographies, time zones, research projects, etc. in his explanations. I hope that one day I will be able to an interpret a landscape the way he can.
Comprehensive and it seems to very much be a course on applied management. I'm not sure how many other FES courses do this.
The wealth of knowledge I learned about forest ecology and management and the field trips which helped to solidify what we learned about in class and the readings
The readings, Mark's generosity during field trips and field trips when the weather was slightly above freezing, facilitating brain function.
The field trips!!
Mark is an incredibly involved teacher and i appreciated his thought-process and lectures.
The field trips were what really helped make the content clear. The instructor was really interested in us learning and willing to help if there were problems with the content.
Management, ethics and knowledge were taught together.

The course does a great job at introducing you to silvicultural topics. It's not a deep dive by any means, but you feel like you have a sense of how the entire ecosystem of forestry operates after taking Silviculture.
The fieldtrips were incredibly valuable--very good practice and able to really see how to apply things.

The course cover a very comprehensive range of concepts that are important to manage a forest. The concepts covered from forest ecology, forest dynamics, botany to forest management to specific uses, such as recreation, water supply and quality, aesthetics, wood and others. The practice is very important to give the students the opportunity of applying the knowledge gained in class.
Field trips--concreted the information taught in class. A good number and all (except, perhaps, the urban forestry piece, which was covered in mods) extremely valuable.
Field trips. Field work.
Field trips

There was a wealth of information shared by the professor in the course. The field trips were also an excellent aspect. They give important opportunity to understand things in the field and not just from slides and lectures.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: As much as I liked the field trips, I definitely think that maybe one field trip could be cut out, as the field trips add a huge time commitment to this course.
Fewer tangents in lectures, and in general less talking on field trips.
Clarity of material, shouldn't be expected to go on all 7 field trips
the field trips should work to better prepare students for the prescription exam. we should practice exercises that will be tested on the prescription.

The initial field trips were actually quite a bit of lecture and so calling them field-lectures as opposed to field trips might be more appropriate. That way you don't get people's hopes up. Mark's encyclopedic knowledge of silviculture and wealth of enthusiasm and experience can also hinder comprehension at times because there are so many concepts being covered at once that it is hard to distill concepts and see with clarity through the diversity of ideas and examples being discussed. Scheduling - please try not to rearrange field trips on short notice to cover missed material in lectures. Field trip coordination - it might be nice to have everyone's cell phone numbers, or to organize a whats app or group me group so that people can communicate more effectively on field trips. This is ideal for TAs to do. Move TA review sessions to a different time slot so that they do not conflict with lunch talks.
Giving up 6-7 days for field trips a semester is difficult. That, in essence, is an additional week of class.

A periodic overview and summary of key concepts and terms, and how those related to one another and past/future material, would have been helpful. There was so much great information, but sometimes key concepts got buried along with information that while interesting, wasn't as practical/useful. I also felt that the exams could be improved. I felt that there was a disjoint between what I understood to be the key concepts of the class and many of the exam questions, which were often focused on trivial or random bits of information rather than demonstrating the main takeaways. Lastly, I really appreciated the silviculture prescription exercise and exam. I felt like this was one of the most useful concepts of the class. I would have done more of these practice exercises in different settings (urban as well as at Yale Meyers) and for different management goals (e.g. water and wildlife conservation) instead of just timber.
Organization and connection of concepts.
It is easy to get lost in the lecture and it is sometimes hard to pull out what is important.
You should institute a no laptop policy and teach the class in a smaller room.
Mark is a little long winded and takes a while to get to the point. He is very thorough but could condense lectures down a bit. Extra time could be used in more participatory ways.

The pace is too fast and the amount of information given in class is hard to follow and absorb. However, I understand that the objetive of this course is very ambitions and any cut would affect the students' learning.
more homework assignments, small research projects and maybe less lecture.
time management

Lectures present a valuable amount of material. Questions are taken and answered well, but the pace of the lectures can discourage student questions. Some way of "tightening up" the presentation of the material in lectures to leave time for a short period of questions and discussion would be helpful. Some portion of lectures seem like tangents to the key material.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was wonderful to see the concepts covered in lecture outside in the field. Excellent!
The tutorials were very helpful, but mostly focused on studying for the exams. I would have liked to have had maybe a tutorial once a week/every other week, to help synthesize key concepts.
The readings sometimes matched up with the lectures - but often not.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is a very valuable course for forestry students, both MF and MFS.
more focus on managing forests but also broader management concepts introduced in the course, which makes it useful for any environmental manager
Mentioned this earlier, but I'm less interested in management. However, it's good to be aware of the techniques and considerations that happen when managing forested lands.
This course forms the basis of the MF degree and is especially important for someone without a forestry background.
This course is central to my program and flows well from Stand Dynamics. I also feel well prepared for management plans next fall.

I am looking for learning about forest restoration so the course was very important to understand how to conduct natural regeneration and how to measure forest stands to ensure multiple uses. I am looking at restoration as a strategy to rehabilitate forest ecosystems, but also to bring economic and social impacts, such as income generation and women empowerment. In this case, the course was essential to learn how the different types of management and treatments could dialogue with the different uses we want to give to the forests (old growth or degraded areas).
I recommend this for those students in the lands and landscapes conservation field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to see forest ecology from a more applied side
Interested in forest management as part of a broader toolkit
wanted to understand management concepts and more practical information
This is course is so amazing and one of the key areas in which I wanted to grow professionally and academically upon coming to FES.
Curiosity and exposure to forest management
Interest in the subject and Mark's interesting reputation
I wanted an overview of the fundamentals of forest management.
It is an important part of the FES experience!
As an MF student it is mandatory, but also key to understanding forestry.
Because I am looking for learning about forest restoration and hot make a more effective use of the forest considering different uses that it can have.
My decisions as an environmental manager will affect treatment of lands on the ground and formation of regulations in conservation easements.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I have a good understanding of silvicultural practices
Yes, but much of this has to be experienced hands-on to really be retained in my opinion
yes
Absolutely. I only wish we had had even more practical field time to practice these concepts.
Yes

Overall, yes. I have a much better understanding of how forests and forest management function. Personally, I would have liked to spend more classes on the management implications at the end of the course, but I understand that different students have different interests.
Yes.
Yes, I learned an incredible amount over one semester, it's pretty amazing how much material is covered.
Yes! A lot! The course is very comprehensive, I just think that we could have had more practical exercises.
Yes, absolutely.
Yes, great intro to world of silviculture!
The course exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to be in the field and see how much our prescriptions and perspectives on how to manage forest stands varied.
There was group work on the field trips, which I found very helpful.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared for the amount of time you will spend in lecture and on field trips. Other than that, this class is a good opportunity to learn about silviculture, and you will come away from this class with a lot of knowledge.
Go on the fieldtrips.
Take it if you're really wanting to learn about forest management, or for the entertaining lectures but make sure to do the readings
keep up with the reading and lecture material throughout the semester. review stand dynamics concepts. pay close attention during lecture for small details that might pop up on the exam.
It's great - if you are considering doing anything even remotely related to land use, in the temperate or the tropical regions of the world, you should take this course.
You will gain a great deal of knowledge from the course, but be prepared to spend a great deal of time on it.

This course is 4 credits, and requires a lot of class time between the lectures and the field trips (which you should definitely attend). It will dominate much of your time during the semester, so be prepared for this.
Do readings religiously if you find the class hard to follow or need more background
Go on all the field trips.
Take it!

This course is fantastic and worth the time and effort. It's relevant to more that just MF's. Anyone interested in land conservation or land-related work should take it as it gives a holistic approach to applying land management techniques for multiple objectives. The lectures are long and drone on a bit, but stick with it! Also, the field trips are amazing, so make sure you go on all of them.
Do the readings in advance and go to the tutorials. It's crucial to do the readings along with the classes. Don't let to read before your exam; it affects your learning and it's just too much.
Silviculture is a huge, sprawling field. Pull Mark aside after class or on field trips and ask specific questions relating directly to your area of expertise.

There is a lot of information presented in lectures. I suggest creating summary lecture notes to focus on the key information presented in the lecture slides. The book text for regeneration methods seemed much clearer than the lectures.
